metadata.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Firm of manufacturers of perfumery and hair oils at Ratlam

facts.text: Respondents are a registered firm of manufacturers of perfumery and hair oils at Ratlam in Madhya Bharat, a Part B State, and their goods are sold throughout India.
Assessed for assessment year 1950-51 at rates applicable to income arising in Part A States.

Course of business: sent out agents to various parts of India to canvass orders and sometimes take advance payments in full or part; after deducting expenses, remitted balance to respondents at Ratlam through bank drafts etc.
Goods sent to customers either by V.P.P. or by rail; in rail case, Railway Receipts in favour of self sent through Bank deliverable against payment of Demand Draft drawn on buyers.

Income-tax Officer held major quantity supplied to Part A/C States, sales effected there, payments received there; assessed estimated profit of Rs. 1,60,340 on sales of Rs. 5,09,424 without concessional rebate for Part B States.
Assessee's banker was Bank of India Ltd., Bombay; sale proceeds mainly realised through this Bank.
On appeal, Appellate Asst. Commissioner reduced estimated profit by Rs. 20,000.

Income-tax Appellate Tribunal reduced total income from Part A/C States to Rs. 2,85,376; found income through Post Office (V.P.P.) Rs. 1,23,710 and by rail/Bank drafts Rs. 2,85,376, total Rs. 4,21,955.

Tribunal held advances received with orders and price of V.P.P. goods received at Ratlam (not Part A/C); bank drafts received at Ratlam but sent to Bombay banker for cashing, so received in Part A State (Rs. 2,85,376).
Tribunal referred to Kirloskar Bros. Ltd. v. CIT and distinguished facts.
Both parties applied for reference to High Court under s.66(1) Income-tax Act.
High Court judgment and decree dated September 20, 1955, in Civil Misc. Case No. 40 of 1954, answered both questions in favour of assessees and gave certificate.

legal_issues.text: Whether the receipt of sale proceeds at Ratlam which included the assessee's profits in respect of goods sent by the assessee to customers in Part A or C States by V.P.P. amounted to receipts of income, profits or gains at Ratlam in Part B States?
Whether the bank drafts payable in Part A or C States but received at Ratlam and encashed through the assessee's bankers at Bombay constituted receipts in Part A State?

Whether on the facts and circumstances of this case the payment received from a buyer by a banker in Part A or C States against delivery of Railway Receipt for goods sent by the seller is payment in these States or in Ratlam which was a Part B State.

petitioner_arguments.text: Sale proceeds to the extent of Rs. 2,85,376 were received at Bombay as per printed advice to bankers to hand over goods against payment of demand draft.

respondent_arguments.text: Judgment in CIT v. Ogale Glass Works Ltd. applies; Post Office was agent of assessee.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: CIT v. Ogale Glass Works Ltd. (1955) 1 SCR 185

respondent_arguments.text: Respondents delivered goods to Post Office at instance of buyer; Post Office acted as bailee for transmission.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: The Badische Anilin Und Soda Fabrik v. The Basle Chemical Works (1898) AC 200

court_reasoning.text: Under V.P.P. system, Post Office is agent of seller for recovery of price; payment to Post Office is payment to seller at place of delivery (Part A/C States); seller retains control until payment; falls under s.25 Sale of Goods Act (conditional appropriation).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Income in respect of V.P.P. goods received in Part A/C States, not Ratlam.

court_reasoning.text: Ogale Glass Works principle has no application as it did not deal with sale of goods or receipt of price against delivery.

For rail despatches, Railway Receipts sent with demand drafts; delivered only on payment; conditional appropriation under s.25 Sale of Goods Act; performed in Part A/C States where payment to Bank as agent of seller.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Income received in Part A/C States, not Ratlam.

court_reasoning.text: Kirloskar Bros. facts different; here bankers hand over goods against demand draft, not unconditional discharge.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Agreed with AAC that Rs. 2,85,376 received at Bombay.

holdings.text: Receipt of sale proceeds for V.P.P. goods to Part A/C States amounted to receipt of income in Part A/C States, not Ratlam (Part B).
Bank drafts received at Ratlam but encashed through Bombay bankers constituted receipts in Part A State.
Payments received by banker in Part A/C States against delivery of Railway Receipts are payments in those States, not Ratlam.
Respondents not entitled to concessional rate of taxation applicable to Part B States.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kirloskar Bros. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Tribunal distinguished facts; not unconditional discharge.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Ogale Glass Works Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Principle has no application to sale of goods or receipt of price against delivery.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mothi Rungaya Chetty v. The Secretary of State for India
precedents_cited.relevance: Post Office failing to recover price liable in damages to seller.
If seller sends with direction not to deliver till payment, appropriation conditional; property does not pass till price paid.
Goods pass at place where price is paid.

precedents_cited.case_name: The Badische Anilin Und Soda Fabrik v. The Basle Chemical Works
precedents_cited.relevance: No control over goods till price paid or conditional delivery; not about passing of ownership.

precedents_cited.case_name: Narain Swadeshi Weaving Mills v. The Commissioner of Excess Profits Tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Reframed question as done in this case.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Reference by Tribunal to High Court.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Sale of Goods Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Seller reserves right of disposal until conditions fulfilled; conditional appropriation; property does not pass till price paid.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Contract Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Bailee to deal with goods according to directions of bailor; receives price on behalf of seller.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; both questions answered in favour of Commissioner; income, profits and gains from V.P.P. and rail despatches to Part A/C States received there, not at Ratlam; respondents not entitled to concessional Part B rates.
outcome.relief_granted: Reversal of High Court judgment in favour of Commissioner.

key_quotes.text: The Post Office is an agent for the seller and receives the price from the buyer at the place of delivery for transmission to the seller.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Determines place of receipt of income under V.P.P.

key_quotes.text: Under the V.P.P. system the seller retains control over the goods right up to the time the goods are delivered to the buyer against payment of price.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains conditional appropriation under s.25 Sale of Goods Act.

key_quotes.text: The income in the present case was therefore received in Part A or Part C States and not in Ratlam.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on place of income receipt.
